text:
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: MRS MARION EVA MEACHAM

Present Address: DEWAR LAKE SASK.

Pioneer Address: FLAXCOMBE SASK 1211

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 12 families

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 6

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Not too often as transportation was not so good.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sunday

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Mostly without an invitation, as I was too far to travel an invitation.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, people would have been hurt if you did not.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Sometimes the term potluck was used, but usually people were not ashamed of what they had to serve, as they had good healthy meals planned and were satisfied by what they had anyone.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Lunch of sandwiches, coffee, tea, candy, homemade cake, etc.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Whole families usually went, as very few had helpers on them to worry about them. Sometimes, someone had to stay back after cattle moved they waited.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? A few putting bees none for building as very few had a big house or barn.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe parties in the homes about once a month in the winter. A lot of them were just exercise parties everyone bringing lunch, cards and games were played, a few dances were held if the house was large enough we even had a piano, organ, violin, banjo, the music with sometimes dancing. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. That would be impossible, unless a man was here. I served the parties at the end of 1911-13 brought by Seals for the war effort, also Bill was doing his part. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Not particular, always tried to cover most of them in the winter unless they didn't have room and meetings were held in the fall of the year, so by as there were only three months, also Mr. Boyd conducted a music class and meetings were held once monthly, again for games and between singing with lunch served after going home.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 2 families.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 6

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Not too often as transportation was not so good.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Mostly without an invitation as it was too far to send an invitation.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, people would have been hurt if you did not.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Sometimes the term "potluck" was used, but mostly people were not ashamed of what they had to serve as they had good healthy meals planned for and were satisfied with what we went anywhere.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Lunch at sandwich, cake sale, often candy home made or pops. We often made candy or pop corn with games for a surprise party.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Whole family usually went as very few had plants or things to worry about. Usually someone had to stay back after cattle work they wanted.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? A few gathering bees none for building as very few had a big house or barn.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe, parties in the homes about once a month in the winter. A lot of them were just surprise parties everyone bringing lunch, cards and games were played. A few dances were held if the house was large enough or we had them in a granary, church organ & violin doing the music with some harmonica.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. That would be impossible unless a diary was kept. I guess the parties were the first 2 or 3 years 1912-13. 1914 brought the school for the war effort when hall was being used for classes. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Not particular at all, we tried to cover most of the town in the winter unless they didn't have room and mostly only in the fall of the year too by as then were only three. Also Mr. Boyd conducted a music class and most of the time met once monthly, 8 min for games and between singing with lunch served before going home.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go? — in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "make polichuk" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in unexpectedly?

Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "mock after the plowing"?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "teens" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe briefly. How often were they held? What kind of games were played?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

They have been described there except we used to have a special and concert hall dance in June time. Also debates with dance, a play get-up by neighbors and dance. Page 29 is very good. The ladies took down from curtains with a light behind, or the piano set at a side piece, a kid as a box.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

All of it in our school as we close by of mile until about 1934 halls were closed. People add more houses, and could travel farther than we could go to town and manage for entertainments. Then travelling shows would come once or twice a year.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?).

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Yes.

How were babies and small children provided for? Put to bed in a corner or any place available.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Inside of room of not-blanketed.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Wist, whist, Latins & Co.

Was there card playing for a prize? Not a fixed lot from 1914-15.

What dances were popular? Yes.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Not very much.

The non-dancers just didn't go. We were all very much of the same religion so there wasn't much trouble. In fact, we had a good time.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Not very much.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, piano, etc.)

9. When was your first community hall built?

   What material was it made of?
   How large was it?
   Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

   Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?
   To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did it make it easier to use the local school house for district gatherings and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?))

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 6, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? What were they?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? Not very as no one had a parlor and mostly only one good and "fast" to go.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes, but not many usually there were a party dance or something similar. Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Red Cross in 1917, all this was work had been done before that.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Only in town and not all the farmers belonged.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Yes.

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality or "wagons" do you remember in small towns such as Butler, etc.? Tell when calling, visiting, parties, etc., were treated especially formally.

13. Was the obsolete known in your community? If so, how was it used?

14. Describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how often they were held, any incidents connected with them, etc.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many members belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

27. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? If so, when was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space on the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

There were United Farmers in Claycomb.

Grain Growers Association farmers union.

Had bees. Some started by 1914. I do not know too much about them.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

concerts, plays and dances.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? Keller office building.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Once in a while. Being only 14 at the time I never attended.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? A few. Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? The minister.

What were the slides about? Other countries and their habits.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Jump rope, pull away, tug, hide and seek, pop in a hole.

Girls and boys mostly played the same thing.

We all liked skipping, stomping, exercise of any kind, especially in winter.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Stone.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1924, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, aims and purposes who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or was scattered in the town or village and included the surrounding countryside. If these organizations met in the church, please indicate the organization(s) with which they were associated.

What were the names of these organizations?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, give details of the speakers, topics discussed, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (mumblety-peg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? What games did girls play in summer (jump rope, hopscotch, etc.)? What games did children play in winter (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

23. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Whist," "Polo," "Tin," "Mather," checkers, chess, or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only two children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. 

Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, reptiles or other objects or animals, or games like the snowball? 

24. Picnics and sports.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give year and month if possible. 

26. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

27. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups for special meals? 

28. What did you have to eat and drink? 

29. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

30. What was the date of the first one that had been held? 

31. What was the date of the first one that had been held? 

32. What was the date of the first one that had been held?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc., talk about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable. There are very few new and not all the fun we used to have, just a few fast races. Many places they have separate beaches. People sit around in cars or just visit, everyone as two danced up to enjoy themselves for fear of getting sticky. People are going in groups and sets more and don't mix. We are three religious and dead people in each group.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). Baseball & Hockey were the main sports, baseball men and women both took part although there were all men teams as well mostly played at short days in town. Deck-up games were played of friends. But now there's been between today and nowadays there aren't enough young people to make a team unless a large town.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? Not any in one community but made up of several.

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). There wasn't any.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of places which you know of in this county, such as the large community or private school or Sunday School, prominent family, etc., and briefly explain why they are held in high regard.

35. What changes have been made in this place since the last census?

36. Describe the sports which are popular in your community in the early years.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

Books: Children's Books, Doctor Books, Carpenter Books, as my father was a carpenter, he was contractor for the first post office in Saskatchewan and many others.

The life of Queen Victoria, many old school books, stories from P. L. Travers, some of Dickens, Louisa May Alcott books, The Begin Series, the usual story books, Hamlet, Edgar Allan Poe, Harold Wright books, Jane Stanhope Porter books, and many others that will come back and never returned.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Most of them had some.

What kind of books and how many? I do not know.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Only to a few close ones.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? I do not remember any.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? Shortly after the school started.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Only what the school children took home for them.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Not that I know of. Most of them had had an education of some kind before they came. Their families had come from U.S.A.
40. Was there an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

Then was the sports day usually held (last month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

REMEMBER:

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheet if necessary.)

43. How many of your neighbors bought books with them? (Not known)

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? (Only in a few cases)

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? (Give details, if possible)

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? (Give details and dates)

48. Was there a school library? (Yes)

When was it begun? (Shortly after the school started)

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? (Only in school children's book rooms)

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material? (Not used)
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? 

When was it started? 
Who started it?

Is it still in existence?
If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? 

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others. 

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? 

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have? 

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started?
   Is it still in existence? If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, whether it was free, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? (Please list them.)

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? If so, give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Mouth organ, auto harp, and accordion and phonograph. The auto harp and phonograph being bought in each town between 1906-1916.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Some had organs, violins.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. Organ in 1916; a piano in fall of 1916.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe, nearly always at any home we sang around the piano or organ and there was always music at entertainments; some had singing verses to sing together.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Mostly hymns and the old ballads, also some of the newer songs especially the first world war songs were sung.

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

Not unless it was Scotch songs. Both mother & father's folk were from Scotland, mother's folk were Gaelic.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

We have made up lyrics and sang them for local festivals for entertainment.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started?
Who started it? How long did it continue?
How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?
What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where they came from.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe, giving dates and places.

In the community? (Were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? In the community?

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the family? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? If so, who started it? When was it started? How long did it continue? How many were in it? Who was bandleader? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances. No.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? No.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain. No.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

The only one that I know of is Mr. Stanley Jenkins who having club facilities took a great interest in everything pertaining to the weather, birds, and their habits, recorded all the flowers names and any information he could get on them and many other things as well as music (tracks) you could get in contact with him at his home in University Avenue.

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important in your community now as it was with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests:

66. Do you have any "collections," such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)
